name: AI for Learning
description: AI assistants like ChatGPT and Claude are powerful learning tools—but only if you use them correctly. This topic teaches you how to use AI to deepen your understanding, not bypass it. You'll learn the difference between asking AI to explain something vs. asking it to do something for you.

learning_steps.text: Watch: Responsible AI with GitHub Copilot
learning_steps.title: Responsible AI with GitHub Copilot
learning_steps.description: This Microsoft Learn module covers responsible AI usage—understanding the risks, limitations, and ethical considerations when using AI coding tools. Takes about 15 minutes.

Before using AI tools, internalize these principles:

• AI should quiz YOU, not answer FOR you
• If you can't explain what AI suggested, you don't understand it
• Struggle is part of learning—don't eliminate it entirely
• Use AI to go deeper on topics you've already attempted
• The goal is to become independent, not dependent
Instead of asking AI for answers, ask it to question you. This builds real understanding.
learning_steps.code:
WRONG: "Explain how Python decorators work"

RIGHT: "I think I understand Python decorators. I'm going to explain them to you, and please ask me clarifying questions if my explanation is unclear or incorrect. Don't give me the answer—just ask questions until I get it right.

My explanation: A decorator is..."

learning_steps.description: After AI explains something, explain it back in your own words and ask if you got it right.
learning_steps.code:
Step 1: Ask AI to explain a concept you're struggling with
Step 2: Read the explanation carefully
Step 3: Close the AI response and write your own explanation
Step 4: Ask AI: "Here's my understanding of [concept]. Is this correct? What am I missing?"

This forces active processing instead of passive reading.

learning_steps.description: When your code has a bug, don't paste it and ask "fix this." Instead:
learning_steps.code:
WRONG: "Fix this code: [paste code]"

RIGHT: "I have a bug in my code. Here's what I expected to happen: [expected]. Here's what actually happens: [actual]. I've tried: [your attempts]. Can you ask me questions to help me find the issue?"

This keeps you in the driver's seat of debugging.

learning_steps.description:
Open your Journal API from Phase 2. Pick a function you wrote and:

1. Explain to AI what the function does (without showing the code)
2. Ask AI to quiz you on edge cases you might have missed
3. Ask AI what improvements an experienced developer might suggest
4. Implement the improvements YOURSELF based on the feedback

Don't let AI write the improved code—you write it.

questions.prompt: How would you distinguish between using AI to accelerate learning versus using it to skip learning? Give examples of each.
Walk me through how you would use AI to help debug code without having it solve the problem for you.

test_knowledge_prompts: Can you quiz me on when to use AI for learning vs. when to struggle on my own?
Can you ask me to demonstrate the Socratic method for learning a concept?
Can you challenge me on how I would debug code with AI assistance?

learning_objectives.text: Understand when AI helps learning vs. hinders it
Practice the Socratic method with an AI assistant
Review Phase 2 code using AI as a learning partner
